title: 111_s1938
content: The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" includes provisions for distracted driving incentive grants, a national education program, research and data collection, a research program, an FCC report on distracted driving technology, provision of information to states, regulations for commercial motor vehicles and school buses, and funding. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" offers distracted driving incentive grants to states that enforce laws prohibiting texting while driving as a primary offense with fines and penalties for violations. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" offers grants to states enforcing laws against handheld cellphone use while driving, with increased penalties for violations. The statute prohibits holding a cellphone for calls, allows hands-free devices, makes violations a primary offense, includes distracted driving in driver's license exams, and establishes specific requirements. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" enforces laws against handheld cellphone use while driving, with increased penalties for violations. It prohibits holding a cellphone for calls, allows hands-free devices, makes violations a primary offense, includes distracted driving in driver's license exams, and establishes specific requirements for fines and penalties. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" prohibits handheld cellphone use while driving, with exceptions for emergency services personnel and certain commercial drivers. The Secretary will grant funds to states that enact or maintain laws meeting specific requirements. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" provides grants to qualifying States for enforcing distracted driving laws and promoting public awareness. States must use at least 50% of the grant for education, advertising, traffic signs, and law enforcement related to distracted driving. Up to 50% of the grant can be used for other traffic safety projects. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" provides grants to States for traffic safety projects that improve traffic safety and meet specific criteria. Definitions in the Act include terms like driving, hands-free device, and personal wireless communications device. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" defines terms like personal wireless communications device as a device for transmitting personal wireless services, primary offense as an offense warranting a citation, and texting as entering data into a personal wireless device. The "Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009" defines a personal wireless communications device as a device for transmitting personal wireless services and prohibits manually entering data for texting or electronic communication. A conforming amendment is made to the table of contents for chapter 4 of title 23, United States Code. SEC. 3. Distracted driving national education program. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will conduct high-visibility campaigns on distracted driving for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 to educate the public about the risks of texting and using wireless devices while driving. Funding may be used for advertising purposes. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will use available funds for advertising to promote traffic safety education campaigns, including targeting non-English speaking populations and jurisdictions with laws against texting while driving. Coordination with states may occur to align campaigns with enforcement efforts. State laws prohibit texting while driving or using personal wireless devices. The Administrator will annually evaluate the effectiveness of education and advertising campaigns, reporting results to relevant committees. SEC. 4. RESEARCH AND DATA COLLECTION. Section 408(e)(2) of title 23, United States Code is amended to include data elements on the impact of using electronic devices while driving. State and local governments must ensure official vehicle accident reports include a section to note the use of personal wireless communications. The amendment requires law enforcement officers to record information about the use of personal wireless communications devices by drivers involved in accidents and incorporate this data into the traffic safety information system. This amendment applies to grants under section 408 of title 23, United States Code, for fiscal years starting after fiscal year 2010. SEC. 5. RESEARCH PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a research program to study distracted driving by passenger and commercial vehicle drivers, including driver behavior, vehicle technology, and portable electronic devices commonly used in vehicles. Research contracts may be granted to non-governmental entities for this purpose, with limitations on contracting with entities that produce or sell electronic equipment for vehicles. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a research program to study distracted driving by passenger and commercial vehicle drivers, including driver behavior, vehicle technology, and portable electronic devices commonly used in vehicles. Research contracts may be granted to non-governmental entities for this purpose, with limitations on contracting with entities that produce or sell electronic equipment for vehicles. The research will focus on passenger or commercial vehicles. Within 180 days of enactment, the FCC must submit a report to Congress on data collection for reducing distracted driving with personal communication devices, utilizing wireless technology, and existing authority. Additionally, information will be provided to states. SEC. 7 exempts the provision of information to states on texting while driving and the use of personal wireless devices while driving from certain regulations. SEC. 8 addresses commercial motor vehicles and school buses. The Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009 mandates regulations on the use of distracting devices in commercial motor vehicles and school buses within a year of enactment. The Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009 requires regulations on the use of distracting devices in school buses and commercial motor vehicles. The Secretary will base regulations on accident data analysis and ongoing research, prohibiting device use that interferes with safe driving. Permitted use may be allowed in emergency situations for driver or public safety. The Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009 mandates regulations on distracting devices in school buses and commercial vehicles. The amendment adds a new section to the table of contents for chapter 311 of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 9. FUNDING. Section 2001(a) of Public Law 109-59 is amended to allocate $94,500,000 for fiscal year 2010 and 2011. Any unallocated funds after July 1 of a fiscal year will be allocated to States meeting specific criteria. Additionally, $30,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2010 and 2011 is designated for the Distracted Driving Prevention Act of 2009.
